Speaker.P: The targets in the current Programme for National Recovery require, over the five year period 1988-1992, a doubling of foreign visitor numbers to over four million per annum, an increase in foreign revenue of £500 million, and the creation of 25,000 jobs in the Irish economy. These targets necessitate an annual average increase of almost 15 per cent in foreign tourism numbers and revenue.

The sector remains on target as we approach the end of this, the third year, of the five year tourism growth plan. Current market estimates indicate that visitor numbers will top three million this year, up some 1.1 million on the 1987 base year figure, and representing a cumulative average increase of 15 per cent per annum since 1988. Annual foreign tourism revenue grew by £258 million by the end of last year, representing over 50 per cent of the five year target, and creating an additional 10,500 jobs in the Irish economy over the years 1988 and 1989.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dublin Public Transport.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: when it is intended to introduce a rapid surface or underground public transport system in the greater Dublin area.

in respect of the proposed rapid rail link to Tallaght, Dublin 24 which was planned by CIE in the early seventies (1) when, and by which Minister, a decision was first taken not to proceed with the project, (2) whether there are still plans in his Department for the carrying out of the rapid rail project, (3) whether he has ensured that the land originally earmarked for the rapid rail link has been retained in public ownership; and if he will make a statement on current policy regarding phase two of DART - the rail link to Tallaght town centre via Clondalkin.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 26 and 94 together.

The Government decided in 1987 that no further consideration should be given to extending the DART system, because of the high costs of such development and the scarcity of financial resources. Following this decision CIE submitted transport investment plans for the greater Dublin area involving bus-based options and diesel services on existing lines.

Most of the bus proposals in the plans have already been implemented. The plans also propose the construction of four new stations on the railway line from Maynooth to the city centre. I am pleased to say that these new stations were opened last July and that the project has been included for EC assistance in the operational programme for peripherality.

MainHeading.P: The investment plans prepared by CIE also included proposals for a commuter diesel rail service on the line from Clondalkin to the city with eight new stations and a feeder bus service to Tallaght. This project is also included in the operational programme. Assistance from the programme has been made conditional on the outcome of a socio-economic cost benefit analysis of the proposed investment. This examination will be undertaken shortly and it is expected that it will confirm the merits of proceeding with the project as a matter of urgency.

I am also looking at other options for meeting the public transport needs of the city and in this connection I have established a high level working group to asses and report on the feasibility of rail and busway options for public passenger transport in relation to the former Harcourt Street railway line and the Tallaght area. I expect to receive the report of the group shortly.
I understand that the land reserved for a rail link to Tallaght via Cherry Orchard has been kept free of development and that the bulk of it is in public ownership.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Light Aircraft Insurance Cover.

Qst.hpid: Tomás Mac Giolla Tomás Mac Giolla
Qst.Quest: if he will consider introducing legislation requiring insurance cover for light aircraft, in view of the possible dangers to third parties from accidents; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: Section 17 of the Air Navigation and Transport Act 1988 provides that I can impose an obligation on owners or operators of aircraft to insure against, or otherwise make financial provision to meet, liability arising in relation to loss or damage resulting from the operation of their aircraft.

MainHeading.P: The question of making an order under section 17 of the 1988 Act has been under examination in my Department and that examination is continuing. Having regard to the fact, however, that in most other European states there is no statutory requirement on the owners or operators of private aircraft to insure against liability for such loss or damage, I have arranged as part of the examination being carried out by my Department, that the representatives of the aviation industry and the private aircraft owners will be consulted in this matter through the Air Navigation Services Office Advisory Council.

Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself that the diversification in marketing and promotion of tourism in County Kerry between Bord Fáilte and SFADCo is in the best interest of the industry in both County Kerry and nationally; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: Bord Fáilte, in addition to its responsibilities for overseas marketing, also retains overall responsibility for co-ordinating marketing and promotion on a national level to ensure a consistent approach to the implementation of national tourism policy.

The tourism functions which SFADCo have assumed for the Mid-West region, including North Kerry, related to product development, the provision of visitor information services, and promotion of the region in the home market. SFADCo liaise regularly with Bord Fáilte, and with regional tourism organisations for adjoining regions, like Cork-Kerry, in the case of specific projects so as to develop the tourism potential of the area in the best interests of the industry both in Co. Kerry and nationally.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: whether he has satisfied himself that the DART system has the ability to meet increasing demand from passengers for peak hour travel; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: DART has proved to be very successful with the number of passengers carried having increased from 11.7 million in 1985 to just over 15 million in 1989, an increase of over 28 per cent.
Irish Rail have responded to the increase to peak passenger carryings by adjusting the timetable to maximise the use of rolling stock.
I am informed by the chairman of CIE that the existing DART fleet is adequate to cater for any further increase in passengers in the foreseeable future.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Rehousing of Dublin Corporation Tenants.

Qst.Quest: if he has discussed with Irish Rail the request made by Dublin Corporation for a narrow strip of land along the Royal Canal near Spencer Dock Bridge, Dublin 1, in addition to the smaller site already under negotiation to enable Dublin Corporation to rehouse the tenants of the Sheriff Street flats; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan) Seamus Brennan
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism and Transport (Mr. S. Brennan)
Speaker.P: My Department has been in contact with CIE about the question of having land owned by the board made available to Dublin Corporation to rehouse tenants displaced from the Sheriff Street Area.

I have been informed that the board recently agreed terms with the corporation for sale of a site at Spencer Avenue. I also understand that there have been discussions between the board and the corporation about the sale of other sites.

I should explain to the Deputy that CIE have a statutory obligation not to dispose of property which is required for the purposes of the undertaking. I fully appreciate the need to rehouse the tenants of Sheriff Street Flats and I raised with CIE the question of disposing to Dublin Corporation the particular strip of land to which the Deputy's question refers. CIE have indicated, however, that they wish to reserve this land for possible future railway development.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to claims by Amnesty International that there are grave and widespread human rights violations in SriLanka; his views on these claims; if he has contacted the SriLankan authorities on the matter, or raised the issue at an appropriate international forum; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
if his attention has been drawn to the widespread violations of human rights in SriLanka as highlighted by Amnesty International and if he will raise Ireland's concern at EC and United Nations level.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. Collins) Gerard Collins
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 43 and 45 together.

I am aware of the upsurge of hostilities in Sri Lanka and of the disturbing reports of human rights abuses there. On 22 October, Ireland joined with its partners in the European Community in issuing a declaration on Sri Lanka. The European Community and its member states deplored the resurgence of hostilities initiated by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam in June and the misery thus caused to the civilian population in the affected parts of the country. The Community, while recognising the serious difficulties faced by the SriLankan Government, urged that only minimum necessary force be used in restoring peace and maintaining order in the country.

Ireland and its partners in the Community have regularly conveyed their concerns on the issue of human rights to the Sri Lankan authorities. They have particularly urged the Sri Lankan Government to act against the death squads and to make every effort to bring the perpetrators of such killings to justice.

The issue of human rights in Sri Lanka was also raised by the European Community and its member states on 26 November, in the Third Committee of the United Nations which deals with human rights issues.

As an indication of the extent of their concern on human rights in Sri Lanka, the Community and its member states have drawn attention to the fact that they will be considering their future assistance for the development of Sri Lanka's economy with reference, among other factors, to the Government's performance in regard to human rights.

Qst.Quest: when it is expected that drainage work will commence, as promised, on the Killerry river which is a tributary of the Bonet and the boundary between Counties Sligo and Leitrim.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. A. Reynolds) Albert Reynolds
Speaker.P: The Killery river enters the Bonet at a point downstream of Dromahair, County Leitrim. In the preparation of the Bonet catchment drainage scheme a number of these downstream areas were excluded for practical and economic reasons. During the course of scheme works a number of representations were made on behalf of the landowners concerned to have this river included in the scheme and it was decided to re-examine the feasibility of carrying out some works in the area when the scheduled works of the scheme had been completed.

Early indications for a scheme of works were relatively promising and it was decided to process the matter further. However, more recently it has proved necessary to re-examine the scheme as a whole on environmental and economic grounds and it is imperative now that works be curtailed for these reasons. The inclusion of the Killery river in the Bonet scheme could not be justified as the cost would be incommensurate with the benefits to be derived.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Work on Bonet River.

Qst.Quest: when it is intended that some general work will be carried out on the Bonet river between Dromahair and Lough Gill, where conditions have deteriorated considerably arising out of the changed patterns of water flow because of the excellent work done in the arterial drainage of the other sections of the Bonet river.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. A. Reynolds) Albert Reynolds
Speaker.P: The stretch of the River Bonet between Dromahair and Lough Gill was excluded from the Bonet catchment drainage scheme for practical and economic reasons. The channel immediately downstream of Dromahair has a very steep gradient levelling out as it nears the lake. In these lower reaches the channel is greatly influenced by lake levels which would to a large extent negate the effects of any drainage works. In addition the bed of the river is largely composed of rock which would render prohibitive the cost of any works which might be considered.

With regard to the suggestion that drainage upstream has changed the pattern of water flows, the Commissioners of Public Works have had a number of surveys of the area carried out during the course of scheme works and the results show that the drainage scheme has not caused any deterioration of the position. Any flooding which occurs is of shorter duration than existed pre-drainage and the commissioners are satisfied with the capacity of the river to cater for postdrainage flows. The commissioners will, of course, keep the position under review.

Qst.Quest: if he will outline the criteria governing the spreading of blood from meat factories on land; if he has satisfied himself with the classification of blood as a nutrient rather than waste; if he has also satisfied himself that the spreading of blood does not constitute the spread of animal disease such as BSE; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.P: The number of cases under appeal to the Supreme Court on 31 July 1988 was 639 of which on that date 139 had been certified by the appellant solicitor as being ready to proceed. Appeals are not placed in the list until such certificate has been given.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Appointment of Caretaker to Cork School.

Qst.Quest: if she proposes to appoint a full-time and permanent caretaker to St. Vincent's convent school, St. Mary's Road, Cork, which has 815 students, only one principal and is without a caretaker.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The post of caretaker in St. Vincent's Convent School fell vacant in 1987 and was subject to the embargo on the replacement of such staff. I am not, therefore, in a position to approve the appointment of a caretaker to this school.

Qst.Quest: if her attention has been drawn to (a) the serious situation which exists at the Ardee Community School, Ardee, County Louth in relation to the scheme for teaching of the disadvantaged and its effect on this school; (b) that the school did not receive an extra teacher to which they were entitled, but in fact lost one; and (c) the plans she has to rectify the situation; when this decision will be made; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The additional teaching posts to post-primary schools in disadvantaged areas under my Department's circular letter No. 27/90 were allocated on the basis of agreed criteria following discussions with the interested parties. Ardee Community School did not receive an allocation under this scheme. However, I would point out that the school has the services of an ex-quota guidance teacher and an ex-quota remedial teacher.

The board of management of Ardee Community School appealed to my Department for an increase in its teacher allocation for the current session. I am happy to inform the Deputy that an increased allocation is being sanctioned and the board of management have been notified accordingly.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Entry to Arts Degree Course.

Qst.Quest: the reason a person (details supplied) in Waterford who has the required number of points for entry to the Arts degree course in UCG, was not granted a place on the course; if she can assist this person in gaining a place on the course; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Applications for admission to courses in UCG are processed on the basis of the selection procedures operated through the Central Applications Office. My Department have no role in the function of the CAO which is an independent agency established by the relevant third level institutions. The Deputy will appreciate, therefore, that it would not be for my Department to furnish the reply requested.
I would ask the Deputy to address the question directly to the CAO at Tower House, Eglinton Street, Galway.

Qst.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Qst.Quest: the reason a higher education grant was not renewed for a person (details supplied) in County Limerick; and if she will review this case with a view to awarding the grant.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: It is understood from Limerick County Council, the body statutorily entrusted with administration of the scheme in the candidate's area, that a higher education grant was paid on a provisional basis for three years between 1987-88 and 1989-90. The eligibility of holders of provisional awards may be reviewed by the local authority on grounds of means, on an annual basis.

It is also understood from Limerick County Council that the reckonable income in this case for the year ended 5 April 1990 is such as to warrant renewal of grant for the 1990-91 academic year at the rate of full fees and the council will be informing the applicant accordingly.

Qst.Quest: when the full list of inservice courses on assessment for the new junior certificate as discussed with the Teachers' Union of Ireland on 12 October 1990 will issue to schools; and if full substitution arrangements, travel and subsistence will be available for all teachers on these courses.

when the full list of inservice courses on the new syllabus content and methodology as discussed with the Teachers' Union of Ireland and the Association of Secondary Teachers of Ireland in May 1989 will be issued to schools; and if full substitution arrangements, travel and subsistence will be available for all teachers on these courses.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 87 and 88 together.

Inservice training for teachers involved in the new junior certificate programme is provided by way of a series of one-day courses, which are organised nationwide. Three such courses have been held to date and they have dealt mainly with syllabus content and methodology. It is my intention to provide at least two one-day courses per school year up to 1992. As I have already announced in the House the next two courses will be held in late January or early February and in March 1991.

Travelling expenses are payable to course participants. Subsistence is in the form of a midday meal, which is provided at course centres. Substitution costs are not payable by my Department; school managers may close their schools on course days, if they deem it necessary, for the purpose of allowing their teachers to attend the courses.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Negotiation Rights for Teachers.

Qst.Quest: if she intends to provide negotiation rights for vocational teachers on their superannuation entitlements.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Teachers employed by the vocational education committees are governed by the Local Government Superannuation Code. Negotiations in relation to that code take place through the Local Authority and Health Services Conciliation and Arbitration Scheme; the Teachers' Union of Ireland is not a party to that scheme. However, I understand that the parties to the schemes are considering a recent request to the Minister for the Environment from the Teachers' Union of Ireland for access to the scheme and a decision is expected shortly.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Teachers' Conditions of Service.

Qst.Quest: if she intends to provide a negotiating mechanism for national, secondary, vocational, community and comprehensive teachers to discuss their conditions of service.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The scheme of conciliation and arbitration for teachers does not at present provide for negotiations on conditions of service. However, the scheme may be amended if all parties to the scheme agree. My Department and the Department of Finance, have indicated their agreement to negotiating an appropriate amendment to the scheme.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: whether she will agree to the request of the Kinsale and District Association for the Mentally Handicapped to make provision for the education of the handicapped of Kinsale and District Community in the community school plan for Kinsale, County Cork.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: A request from the Kinsale and District Association for the Mentally Handicapped to make provision for the handicapped children of the area in the proposed new community school is under examination. My Department will be in contact with the association when this examination is completed.

Qst.Quest: if there is any way by which a person, at present doing a national diploma in business studies in a regional technical college, can be grant-aided to continue with a degree course in business studies, even though he did not get the necessary honours required for university in the leaving certificate; and if she will make a statement outlining the conditions for grant aiding such a continuation of diploma studies.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: The vocational education committee scheme scholarship and the higher education grants scheme contain provisions under which a holder may, subject to certain conditions, continue to hold a scholarship or grant while proceeding from national diploma to degree level courses.
In order to be eligible for a grant or scholarship a candidate must, however, be eligible for such an award on the basis of the means and academic attainments laid down in the schemes.
